jurisdiction.title: Holy Spirit Catholic School Division - Alberta, Canada

D51E0CE3D785420DA9CDF09E3C6DC2D3.description: Examine Vaudeville as an inspiration for creating dramatizations.

FFC0DB88FC464178A87706807224D5CB.description: Discuss how theatre and drama can connect individuals to culture.

1C919F7A63A1467F9ED3A517F01AB548.description: Explore the ideas of the French Revolution through dramatizations.

43CBD6B2E5884BF790B999EEAC5714CD.description: Use drama vocabulary when responding to or sharing opinions about dramatic works.

A92BD7AF8A304B638FA333FB3AB48AE2.description: Observe a variety of dramatic works

206A8E6B66364222A5576204FBC1F4A9.description: Drama and storytelling traditions existed prior to the colonization of the United States of America, and evolved as more people arrived

3544B4AB61E94B75B7221A8C2CE12101.description: The way in which drama is understood and appreciated has changed throughout history.

D86CE4780E50439FBFC5964F1753CCEB.description: Appreciation of drama can change through active reflection and experience with drama.

F70CF84211534057B21AE44C21422CEE.description: At the turn of the 20th century, American theatre focused on giving characters realistic qualities instead of stereotypical ones

038C1C3ED14C4CBBA2E23C916C3785D9.description: Vaudeville shows from the 1890s to the 1930s included short scenes, magic, contortionists, singers, and dancers

E7DAFBDBC1CC4E13B9360FE480EE5DD8.description: Vaudeville was a popular American form of theatre that was valued for its light and comedic style

826D1ACA244446E5998C1C7B2FE346E7.description: In western societies, women were allowed to act on stage for the first time during the 18th century.

74B727CACFBD453BB2C08FBA70033C45.description: Plays were banned in many areas of the United States during the revolutionary war in order to cut emotional ties to Britain

24ACE9CAF80647769B85ED61979EA5DD.description: Before the colonization of the United States of America, the Indigenous people had rich and historical traditions of storytelling, which continue to be celebrated today.

0F809EC7219744D0A093E1D058E5DB17.description: The proscenium arch was used during the Enlightenment to create a "picture frame" for the audience to look through to create a sense of realism, as seen in The Royal Opera of Versailles

18D184E58F424499A36412B18B29FC44.description: Plays during the French Revolution communicated the ideas of freedom, equality, and brotherhood

8649286B58D14C30B305309393FC6B64.description: Theatre connected the people of France to their culture and values during the French Revolution

89C471F8365D4E6D9B888EA5E7AE13AB.description: Greek and Roman playwrights influenced the Enlightenment, including the works of Aeschylus, Sophocles, Aristophanes, and Euripid

4CCC6D462FAA460290CCB9F47E26B935.description: Drama vocabulary can be used when responding to and sharing opinions about dramatic works

93CBFE01CDD540568EE93401B8A391DF.description: Responses to and appreciation for drama can reflect personal preferences and perspectives

F3281005FC554C938F5D50CE006B77A4.description: Appreciation can shape individual artistry, curiosity, and engagement in drama

BA0ACE92C00C475C8AA403901187D74E.description: Appreciation of drama as an art form can change with experience and inform future decisions about participation in drama

6E720F274B8345E9A134DF5B482FDB57.description: Students relate change to historical events and the evolution of dramatic practices

A81A0327E8AE45B392EECA03490083BE.description: Appreciation: Recognizing beauty, goodness, and truth in drama can be developed by understanding the complexity and richness of great dramatic works, the artists who create and perform them, and the historical and cultural contexts from which they originate

04E75A993DF04EF79614013296D45D3B.description: Describe how feedback was incorporated to clarify or enhance artistic intention.

63BFE3459B854D55AF74FEA0FCC8F679.description: Evaluate the effectiveness of communicating intention in drama.

28AF504AC170410F890F42FFC4529154.description: Problem solve to enhance or refine the intention of a dramatization.

0CF2674A219840A1A62DC2E755D22B07.description: Take creative risks during the process of developing a character, role, or situation

1087D4692CF94A6E8BE57CBC73D3D7C6.description: Participate in drama activities that explore and challenge creative expression.

64FC3BE0EA2343F7884BB75DACE5D008.description: Respond to a variety of stimuli in the creation and exploration of dramatic expression.

080C001B2AAD4E7B833F989E3EB7D048.description: Evaluate how adjustments made to the voice and body are appropriate for the ideas expressed

C12713E461AF4D7692547F41CD58FF7C.description: Practise sustaining a character's status, intention, or feelings.

FB3E2C15F3304E69823A36375639B4EC.description: Demonstrate how voice and body can be combined to represent a character, role, or situation

5CB2C0379357469FAF76E85E07E66816.description: Adjust body, breath, and voice to communicate intention.

DA87E8AD62C54C03BC0D2BC165DBEFCA.description: Participate as an audience member and as a performer in drama

35C9F3112AEE49028D0AAB65C23BEC5D.description: Collaborate to solve staging or movement challenges in a variety of performance spaces

2D6CD2CD07714438A5C42946B9B6AD22.description: Rehearse performances before presenting to an audience

AA987D48B8E249288FF69EA16572F2B7.description: Demonstrate how to follow directions when working in a dramatization

2305AE427B4447DA816B3CC2633A04B5.description: Devise a plan that outlines the requirements needed to rehearse and perform a dramatic work.

64F5F48B46964783A1075ECC40F7F0C5.description: Demonstrate how intention can be communicated through the structure and organization of a dramatization.

2BD9E406D7D84150AD6764C38592D1B6.description: A performer`s intention may emphasize process over product

A8F6DE979DAE46D0AD73D8B0748AF82F.description: Intention can be linked to the purposeful creation, expression, or appreciation of drama.

1F3D0D43C30A4560AB4C7503DDB6F151.description: Intention refers to what a performer means to express

B07A378864FD4EB9BD9058AC4D8B17BB.description: Intention becomes evident to the performer and audience when drama has structure and organization.

1512818D15984E91B7D0DBBE339265C9.description: Creative risk taking can include working individually or in groups trying unfamiliar or new techniques working outside of one's comfort zone

005DDAEE32F24BE59DAE71704AF9B32E.description: Communicating intention can involve creative processes, including decision making in the creation of a dramatization problem solving creative risk taking consideration and implementation of feedback reflection

7AF3451E0AFA4DA69C1FBF5D3F5A9656.description: A performer's artistic intention can be enhanced or refined by viewing, practising, and participating in drama activities

9A5EE22D6D55410996867B2AAEF20004.description: A variety of stimuli can be used to focus intention, including images music poetry stories props artworks

6969AD2A2D23400AA6B85FE6B4381518.description: A character's perspective, experience, and feelings can be intentionally portrayed in dramatic works.

884B10EFD8024D918F2F199541BB63C7.description: A character's intention, point of view, and status can be expressed through body and voice

E6A4714572214895A1D1BCA936A97247.description: Dramatic expression can be created intentionally using the body and voice to communicate status, point of view, and perspective.

FE5EA3EBF542439BAFE9F27D11899E00.description: Dramatizations may be interpreted in a way that differs from what the performer intended

F72EBC370A4246089AAB53B94CFD36F5.description: Directions for structure and organization can include cues, assigned roles, and use of stage areas

CB6137B0976D40E68384F7A1C3AA22B9.description: Structure and organization in a dramatic work can include story structure, with a beginning, problem, and resolution technical elements dramatic forms creating a plan for a dramatization blocking staging choices awareness of the audience points of view, such as firstperson, the audience, or a chosen character rehearsal and performance processes, such as the use of on- and off-stage areas

54B66B3A8DC64A7689CEBCA36847DC6F.description: Students express intention as an integral part of artistic expression in drama

30EA5E5439DD4A7C8D59D74809518D36.description: Creating and Presenting: Ideas can be represented dramatically through artworks that draw upon foundational knowledge

68E409B8DE2244678A934C65790348A9.description: Examine various forms of staging presented in live or recorded performances.

1ECC104D108B4451B8A4DFAF79FC45F3.description: Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of blocking and staging choices.

8F7C17D20CA64CDC882905A5139757CF.description: Combine body positions and stage areas in the exploration of dramatic action

FD9B43522701411DAA94C7D97850891E.description: Respond to verbal cues that direct movement throughout the nine stage areas

1DC05D30BBE2449CB22027A7BDAE6C1A.description: Incorporate technical elements in a dramatization.

650F06BE3D604416BB5F0F55EDBF16E5.description: Participate in vocal and physical warm-ups.

A72900C089E84AB0B8564DA48B593BC1.description: Recognize the connection between body and voice in verbal expression

B1D5568D783A46BAB1012CFC110DE8DF.description: Discuss how inefficient vocal and physical habits can impede expression

98A5B528FEDC421DA3812173F0B0603F.description: Evaluate the use of voice in the development of a character, setting, and mood

3E0386E238E34CB2A4FF210DF927A0F1.description: Examine how the voice can be used to develop authentic characters and stereotypes

DA5F38E18AB2481FA25B499EC28D74FA.description: Examine how the voice can support the believability of a character or situation

F3F1451455FD4056BC1E2B34A332FC42.description: Experiment with how the voice can establish mood or setting in a dramatization.

B1B3FBAB05814F109AAC3ED19BECE7E7.description: Extend vocal production to reflect character

4D2069CB8E7C44D9B8F5EBF3B9DD8D26.description: Evaluate the balance of voices within an ensemble

51F689045E434F8BAE74A105B85A011D.description: Use the voice in unison to communicate intention.

23A559400B554443B659BE27C5110038.description: Discuss how drama experiences contribute to knowing when and how to use the voice appropriately

4C13495D0E5F4803B85AABF4FC1997F9.description: Staging includes the planning and movement of performer(s) on stage

FB3C0B5601184035B11E5E67CF1C7356.description: Staging creates the world of the performance so that the audience can look in

982159AC1D9F4128A05A367DD423F923.description: Staging is the overall design of a performance

B3E0B97784274CDBB993ED463517FAC4.description: Voice work is physical and requires an awareness of body.

0EE999EF2E07431EB35264ABABE1D2B1.description: The voice expresses personality, style, and character.

5215B87839F54390B0A2207E343CDB58.description: The voice can communicate a performer's intention to the audience and other performers

B8363B4EE73D4C759E52C288ACDF12E8.description: Voice is a powerful communication tool that can convey the uniqueness of an individual or ensemble.

A9A8A681E15B471FB90C5283744B1146.description: A director can guide the movement of the performer(s) on stage

A50B78DC18814B6FBD2AF9A0F606E918.description: Blocking is a performer's movement and positioning throughout the nine stage areas

B105E0564FF745F492A45E7D96ABA510.description: Body positions, including full front, profile, and full back, can be used in conjunction with the nine stage areas.

EA8AB0F37F6B47C396AFDE913C6D903F.description: Downstage refers to the area closest to the audience.

F466CAD07FCF46B6B00B3BDCE1AAF33C.description: The names of the nine stage areas originated from the structure of a raked stage, where the stage tilts toward the audience.

263879AEEB884B1FACBB3144A49B3CD4.description: There are nine areas of the stage: upstage right upstage centre upstage left centre right centre centre left downstage right downstage centre downstage left

6EFCD44F43C54DF6B039FD01C3E09C45.description: Dramatic tension can be created through the combination of blocking and technical elements

6FDF14D8F2E74C55B665C3DE7F4BA07B.description: The world of the performance can be created with technical elements, including blocking performers sound sets props costumes lights

A1669C72B1404DD79636B585C60276E6.description: Staging includes technical elements, dramatic forms, and audience placement

F0A8B9E035314FE880FD7323F44BE9A3.description: When staging decisions have a purpose, an audience's experience can be enhanced

04ADB7926E6E4F7FACE9FBF1A3F66D46.description: Vocal control requires awareness of body, breath, and release

AA95FD757BCC4761B66C3F08DA87E09B.description: Vocal hygiene includes efficient projection of voice and voice production.

CD4BBE9379FA4B839E8521A7F1A61ADB.description: By releasing inefficient vocal and physical habits, opportunities for the voice emerge

0AB92043B42347EBBD7ECCBF4D87AD50.description: Voice work can include physical and vocal warm-ups.

871CABCA4E0746D7ABD40115A712EC84.description: The voice can be used to make a character or situation more believable.

F8CD71061FF04DD39993A78CD42A72E8.description: The use of voice can evoke an emotional response from others, focus attention, or drive dramatic action

58023EA6DA1344F6B2B93B2DAF1AE890.description: Intentional production and projection of the voice can communicate feelings, tension, and ease

9FB5A49CE4894686BBB6DDECB614E1FE.description: The setting in a drama can be a visual or auditory representation of the place in which the dramatic situation occurs

C8F9FBC65B5B492384BF404C6A871ED1.description: The mood in a drama refers to the overall emotional quality of a dramatic work

0828C79460F4452CA0C17578EDF46C66.description: Vocal expression can contribute to establishing the mood or setting of a dramatization

2842C0D681AB48638C4B7914D5298862.description: Voice can begin with thought and breath and lead to verbal or nonverbal expression

B9A7AFB591E741C7AE11E486F9F39562.description: Balancing voices within an ensemble requires collaboration and compromise

E8180F48231C4DDA8811361513073487.description: Production of voice as an ensemble requires listening to each other for vocal pitch energy tone volume projection articulation pace phrasing

F3D0CE71EE154E898FD6667D1FEF0565.description: Individual and collective use of voice requires adjustments in volume emphasis accent intonation breathing

FB051A5EB0B94A468F19CAA919927B33.description: A voice can be blended with other voices to create a distinguishable tone

F8ACDB88F58D4BFCA0A9A9B5A04801AD.description: Students associate voice with staging in the development of characters, roles, and situations.

A7ACDD7C4F574BF89A0EE74154E750DC.description: Foundational Elements: Drama literacy is developed through knowledge and application of dramatic processes.
